perturbation.original_text: 9.  NO WARRANTIES.  EACH PARTY PROVIDES ALL MATERIALS AND SERVICES TO THE OTHER PARTY "AS IS."  EACH PARTY DISCLAIMS ALL WARRANTIES AND CONDITIONS, EXPRESS, IMPLIED OR STATUTORY, INCLUDING WITHOUT LIMITATION THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF TITLE, NON-INFRINGEMENT, MERCHANTABILITY, AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. Each party acknowledges that it has not entered into this Agreement in reliance upon any warranty or representation except those specifically set forth herein. Unless an approval process is specified herein, all deliverables provided by one party to the other shall be deemed accepted (for purposes of the UCC) when delivered.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.  NO WARRANTIES.  EACH PARTY PROVIDES ALL MATERIALS AND SERVICES TO THE OTHER PARTY "AS IS," EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY WARRANTED IN EXHIBIT A.  EACH PARTY DISCLAIMS ALL WARRANTIES AND CONDITIONS, EXPRESS, IMPLIED OR STATUTORY, INCLUDING WITHOUT LIMITATION THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF TITLE, NON-INFRINGEMENT, AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE, but NOT MERCHANTABILITY. Each party acknowledges that it has not entered into this Agreement in reliance upon any warranty or representation except those specifically set forth herein, AND THE GUARANTEES OUTLINED IN EXHIBIT A. Unless an approval process is specified herein, all deliverables provided by one party to the other shall be deemed accepted (for purposes of the UCC) when delivered.
perturbation.explanation: The original section explicitly disclaims all warranties, including merchantability. The modified version contradicts this by introducing exceptions: 'EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY WARRANTED IN EXHIBIT A' and explicitly stating merchantability is NOT disclaimed and also indicates that 'GUARANTEES OUTLINED IN EXHIBIT A' are also relied upon. This creates ambiguity, as it is unclear if warranties are fully disclaimed or if Exhibit A provides exceptions, thus creating an in-text contradiction.

perturbation.original_text: 5.1  Rights/Restrictions.  Except as specified in this section, each party may freely use and disclose any information (both individual and aggregated) about Users ("User Data").  Neither party shall disclose any User Data in any manner that permits the User Data to be associated with the other party or permits the targeting of Users on the basis of their status as Users (in theglobe's case) or theglobe users (in Boxlot's case), nor shall a party use the User Data to target Users on the basis of their status as Users (in theglobe's case) or theglobe users (in Boxlot's case).  However, either party may disclose User Data if it is aggregated (in a non-associatable way) with data from multiple online properties.  Each party shall use and disclose User Data only in accordance with the privacy policy under which it was collected.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.1  Rights/Restrictions.  Except as specified in this section and in section 2.9, each party may freely use and disclose any information (both individual and aggregated) about Users ("User Data"), specifically for the purpose of database synchronization as per section 2.9.  Neither party shall disclose any User Data in any manner that permits the User Data to be associated with the other party or permits the targeting of Users on the basis of their status as Users (in theglobe's case) or theglobe users (in Boxlot's case), unless otherwise specified in Section 2.9. However, either party may disclose User Data if it is aggregated (in a non-associatable way) with data from multiple online properties, or if it benefits cross-promotional campaigns outlined in exhibit A. Each party shall use and disclose User Data only in accordance with the privacy policy under which it was collected, except in cases where the legal team grants a waiver.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause restricts use of User Data for targeting users based on their association with the other party. The modified version introduces exceptions tied to Section 2.9 (Database Synchronization), Exhibit A (Cross-promotional Campaigns), and legal waivers, creating conflicting interpretations of what constitutes acceptable use of User Data and adding uncertainty to the initial restrictions. This in-text contradiction makes it unclear when these restrictions apply, leading to potential disputes.

perturbation.original_text: 8.2  Termination for Failure to Perform.  By providing written notice, a party may immediately terminate this Agreement: (a) if the other party materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure that breach within 15 days after receiving written notice of the breach, or (b) as provided in Sections 2.6  [Boxlot Content] or 12.7  [Force Majeure] or Exhibit B.  In addition, by providing written notice, theglobe may immediately terminate this Agreement, or at its option immediately suspend its promotion and other efforts hereunder, in the case of Boxlot's breach of Section 12.1  [Compliance with Laws].
perturbation.changed_text: 8.2  Termination for Failure to Perform.  By providing written notice, a party may immediately terminate this Agreement: (a) if the other party breaches this Agreement and fails to initiate a cure within 15 days after receiving written notice of the breach, with the cure period being subject to good faith negotiation, or (b) as provided in Sections 2.6  [Boxlot Content] or 12.7  [Force Majeure] or Exhibit B, provided those sections are applicable. In addition, by providing written notice, theglobe may terminate this Agreement after providing boxlot with a reasonable chance to rectify the failure to comply, or at its option immediately suspend its promotion and other efforts hereunder, in the case of Boxlot's breach of Section 12.1  [Compliance with Laws], as long as the breach is not caused by an unforeseen change of laws.
perturbation.explanation: The original section allows for immediate termination for material breach with a 15-day cure period. The modified version changes this by removing 'material' and introducing 'initiate a cure' which is then subject to a good faith negotiation, thus making the termination right subject to the other party's willingness to negotiate. It also changes the right to terminate immediately when boxlot violates section 12.1 compliance with law, but adding 'reasonable chance to rectify the failure to comply' which is vague, and then indicates that it only applies 'as long as the breach is not caused by an unforeseen change of laws.' The original termination clause was more firm, but the modified version introduces ambiguity and weakens the termination clause due to the change in conditions to terminate.
